Artist here!
You could have gotten a much more vibrant color out of your pigment with different methods at the end.
1. You were correct in that it just wasnt fine enough. Paint makers usually do a process after grinding called "muddling" which mean smearing the pigment between two glass surfaces for a long time, either mixed with water or the final vehicle.
2. Painters usually don't apply any dark paint like prussian blue isolated and directly from the tube. Store bought prussian blue looks close to black if you just apply it alone, mixing in a tiny bit of white helps get it opaque and vibrant. Without the white its simply a too concentrated blue for us to distinguish it from other dark colors, cause its close to the edge of our visual range. If you want to be a purist and only use the one pigment, then mixing it with gum arabic and using it more like water color would do you well, because then you can just apply a more dilute wash and the white of the paper will lift the color up into that striking visual range

very bold to use oil paint on watercolor paper. below are some art tips in case youre actually interested in painting!

if you plan on using oil paint in the future: use canvas, not watercolor paper. it will hold gesso better. if you don't have any gesso, you can use a mixture of linseed oil, gamsol, and white oil paint. also, the linseed oil you get at art supply stores is also much more expensive than it needs to be. you should be able to get linseed oil in much larger quantities at any store that sells wood (like lowes or home depot).

when actually painting with oils, it will help to wait a day or a day and a half between layers. it will keep the paints from blending too much if you want there to be more definition.

always keep your workspace well ventilated and keep your chemicals and paints away from open flame, as the fumes can be harmful over long exposure and most of the chemicals are flammible.

a big key in making something look less like a child's drawing is value. if you wanted to work primarily with prussian blue then mixing it with differing amounts of white oil paint will give you enough values to work with. ive actually done a few monochromatic oil paintings using only prussian blue and white funnily enough.

Okay I have to make a correction because something you said was just straight up wrong and being a stubborn fine and media arts student I couldn’t let it go. Most oil paints are NOT just oil and pigment, in fact the ones that are are professional or artist grade and they often run over $30 for an ounce (depending of course on the pigment) most oil paints, especially the cheap stuff are about 5% pigment and maybe 20% oil, the other 75% is just fillers that cost next to nothing, this is so the company can save money. There are, however, different grades of oil paint and the grade depends on how much pigment, oil, and filler are in the paint. Ergo, the higher the percentage of oil and pigment and the lower the percentage of fillers, the higher the grade. So yes, most high grade oil paints are just oil and pigment, but most oil paints in general are mostly filler. So now ya have a bit more knowledge. This can easily be avoided though by buying Gambol artist grade paints as those have absolutely no fillers, are extremely smooth, and are extremely well priced at about $20 for a rather large tube. This is because gambol buys bulk pigments for cheap and focuses more on quality than on their profits, and due to this their customer base is extremely loyal and their profits stay high enough for the company to continue to grow.

Fascinating! As an artist-- yes, when working with oils, you want a very thick paper. Watercolor paper is good because it can hold moisture, but a lot of times oils are done on canvas or wood because the oil tends to eat through the paper over time. The turpentine which is needed to make the oils more workable doesn't help either. I think your work was fine for someone who's never worked with oils before! Art is difficult! And honestly even as a professional artist I don't like using oils, they're too slow and finicky for me. But even though I could paint something with oils, I'd never be able to mix up my own paint like this, so don't be too hard on yourself for having a different set of skills.

I'd be interested to see you use some of the pigment for dyeing, as Prussian Blue is a really strong pigment that tends to stain, even when using cheap paints with low pigment count.

challenge accepted:
the double ring with the two ketone groups and the four nitrogens is caffeine,
the benzyl ring with the carboxylic acid group and the hydroxyl group is 2-ol-1-benzoic acid (sorry about the naming), otherwise known as salicylic acid
the molecule above the caffeine is 2-acetoxybenzoic acid, also known as aspirin
the molecule with iron in it is obviously the ferrocyanide (you missed the 4- there, by the way)
the molecule in the middle of the top, next to the aspirin is 2-methyl indole
the molecule to the top left of the salicylic acid is menthol
the molecule in the middle has the formula C20H19N202 and I literally typed that into the browser and its common name is dun dun dun... Nile red http://atb.uq.edu.au/molecule.py?molid=102121 (I'm guessing you named your channel after that?)
ok the chemical formula of the last molecule in the bottom middle is C20H2ON3+ and it's called... dun dun dun... Nile blue.

Prussian blue is also often used to check surface topology and relative flatness. A flat reference like a granite surface plate gets a very thin layer of blue applied and the part to be checked is placed on topped moved around slightly. This transfers some of the blue to only the high spots of the part, letting you see the topology!

Hello nile, this is the easy way to make potassium ferrocyanide

The chemical composition of ferrocyanide is created by heating 10 parts* potassium carbonate with 10 parts* coke and 3 parts* iron turnings. Everything should be in a coarse powder. The coke (fuel) should be produced from coals. Sodium carbonate works fine. *The parts are measured by weight.
While occassionally stirring with an open crucible to full red heat until the emitting of flame in blue and purple are not any loner visible. Cool the solution. Filter the solution, allow to evaporate and the remaining material will begin to crystalize.
Collect the crystals and dissolve them into hot water (boiling removed from the heat source). Cool in a temperature controlled environment, decreasing heat overtime (take your time and do it over a half-day to a day). Large yellow crystals will form of ferrocyanide.
Melt these crystals into a glass container and allow them to cool. Dissolve the melted mass in water and vinegar (50/50) and add 50% of the solution of alcohol. Dissolve in water and crystallize.

You have to be careful of where your steel wool comes from. Some steel wool (from China in my experience) has a fine coating of lead coating the fibers to prevent corrosion. Of course steel wool from the US cannot do this because of our country's hazardous waste regulations. If you do use steel wool with lead rust inhibitor it will ruin this procedure. Also, if you attempt to make ferrous sulfate (copperas), this too will fail because you'll foul your product with LOTS lead sulfate and your product will be unusable.
Steel wool comes coated/lubricated and must be first cleaned in acetone or de-greaser of your choice.

If you want to keep your paper from buckling, put some water in a spray bottle and make it uniformly damp (not wet), THEN tape it down.  The water makes the paper 'swell' and taping it down swollen causes it to stretch as it dries.  You can then gesso it or paint it with reduced buckling.  Watercolorists do this with good watercolor paper, which is tailor made to amplify this stretching attribute and 'take' a lot of water without tearing.

I'm and artist, and I actually make my own paint. I disperse my pigments into mostly waterbourne emulsions. I have some prussian blue from one manufacturer that will coagulate after I disperse it in an acrylic emulsion, rendering it useless in the end. But there is one prussian blue that I have from another manufacturer that is fine after I disperse, having no chemical reaction at all. You should try tinting a white paint with it. Or mixing it into a clear synthetic resin like an automotive clear coat. You can tint the clear coat with it making it a transparent "candy" color. This is a very versatile pigment because it has a dark mass tone to a beautiful blue color of many shades if thinned out.

Just so everyone knows, mixed media is NOT watercolour paper. It can be used for watercolour practice and swatches, but you can't use multiple layers or a lot of water on it or it pills and buckles horrible even if taped down. Which entirely defeats the purpose of using it for watercolour in my opinion. It's safe to use for acrylic and oil paints as well as gouache that doesn't have much water added. Don't make the mistake I made by being cheap with my supplies and getting mixed media instead of actual watercolour paper. Thankfully I could use the mixed media pad I got with my acrylic paint and oil pastels, but it cannot handle watercolour.

Not trying to be negative or anything, just warning any beginning artists around here that your materials will go a LONG way when you get the good stuff.
If anyone is wondering what the difference between mixed media and watercolour paper is I can give some links to explanations.

I suggest synthesizing magnesium euxanthate, a bright yellow pigment known as Indian yellow. Widely used for many centuries, it was banned by the British in the 19th century when it was thought that the raw material from which the color was refined was essentially a concentrate of urine from cattle fed an exclusive diet of mango leaves and water. The evidence for this is now known to be very probably false. Had it been true, of course it would be an instance of animal cruelty. Since then, various substitutes have been used, most based on cadmium sulfide or arylide yellow. These substitutes all lack one interesting characteristic of the historic pigment, which is that true Indian yellow is strongly fluorescent. +NileRed I have an idea to make potassium ferrocyanide from scratch that you can try:
Step 1: turn a good amount of apple seeds and cherry pits (for example) into a powder.
Step 2: transfer the powder into a round botton flask and add some water with a little bit of sulfuric acid into it, then set up for a "pseudo" steam distillation with the condenser filled with cold water and the receiver flask filled with some sodium hydroxide solution. (In this step we are hydrolising the mandelonitrile and amygdalin that is present in the powder into several compounds including HCN, which is co-distilled with the water and reacts with the sodium hydroxide solution to make sodium cyanide.)
Step 3: react the sodium cyanide solution with a mixture of soluble iron (II) and iron (III) salts then slightly acidify the mixture with some dilute hydrochloric acid to create a precipitate of Prussian Blue.
Step 4: filter off the Prussian Blue precipitate and the treat it with a potassium hydroxide solution to make potassium ferrocyanide and iron (III) hydroxide.
Step 5: filter the potassium ferrocyanide solution to separate it from the iron (III) hydroxide and all that it´s left is evaporate the solution to get crystals of potassium ferrocyanide trihydrate.
You can also this Cody'sLab ´s video as a reference: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wz9dcinl330

I would say using the gesso is a must. Otherwise the oil would seep in to the absorbant paper and over time deteorate it quickly in addition to decreasing the amount of binder in the paint which would also be a problem.
When applying the gesso try going in just one direction across the entire paper during the application of one layer. (As the paper is oriented on the screen: try going in a cross direction = left to right and next layer top to bottom) You don't need to have perfect coverage of the paper on your first layer - build it up over time ( specially with thinner paper(100g/m^2) try to not go over the same spot over too many times (in one layer). I noticed the gesso and the paint seemed quite thick try thinning the gesso down with water and the paint with turpentine.
Paper warping - the paper does worp when wet thou then stretches again when fully dry. (With some papers it's a problem even after drying they stay worped, but with an aquarelle paper at 300g/m^2 I would expect it to stretch just fine .) Perhaps try a very diluted coating of animal glue abbout 2-3dkg for 1l of water to pre strech it before applying the gesso. (Also why not use a brush to apply the gesso?)

You asked for a feasible method to procure ferrocyanide? To make ferrocyanide salt for the purpose of making prussian blue might be a bit silly, as the precursor to the ferrocyanide salt can also be used to make blue ferric ferrocyanide as well as ferrous ferricyanide pigments. However, there likely is a feasible way to make potassium ferrocyanide using easily obtained ingredients, if you need it for other things. NurdRage had a video on the production of sodium cyanide a while back. It's blocked now but the recipe lives on through the science madness wiki. I have also seen his method in very old texts, and I have confirmed the process's legitimacy. It yields quite well. The process involves reacting molten sodium hydroxide, carbon, and cyanuric acid. I'd imagine you could use the potassium version of the salts for potassium cyanide. If not, there's probably a way to convert to potassium cyanide from sodium cyanide. Either cyanide salt can directly produce ferric ferrocyanide with addition of ferrous sulfate (or other ferrous salt) and acid. This is a convenient test for presence and concentration of cyanide in solution as the blue pigment indicates cyanide. However, to make potassium ferrocyanide alone, according to this site you do the same thing minus acid - combine ferrous sulfate and potassium cyanide. https://www.911metallurgist.com/blog/iron-in-cyanidation-ferrocyanide-compounds.

The same reaction creates prussian blue if acidified so theoretically pH control might allow an excess of ferrous salt. Probably best to do it cold as well.

Hi NileRed!
First I wanna say that I love your channel so much, and every time when I watch your channel I feel more fulfilled by this surge of knowledge. Thank you for these amazing videos!!
Next thing I would like to say is that I've watched the video published by Cody's lab today and he has mentioned a quite decent way of generating Prussian blue using cherry pits... I did an online search and found that bitter almond can be a very good and somewhat feasible source of cyanide, with each almond able to yield 4-9 mg of hydrogen cyanide...
I kinda figured out a synthesis pathway that bears possibility of not working in practical experiments but should be able to synthesize small amount theoretically... So in Cody's lab he collected and grounded a full bowl or similar amount of cherry pits in oil bath and added strong yet non-volatile acid into those grounded pits to catalyze the decomposition of some cyanogenic glucosides, which yields some decent amount of hydrogen cyanide in a time period of 5 hours around. He then separated the hydrogen cyanide using distillation and immobilized those by conducting the gas produced into sodium hydroxide solution.
I think in this case, we can try to put the gas generated by the hydrolysis of cyanogenic glucoside into a solution containing iron(II) ions and this should yield us some ferrocyanide ions, which can be used to react with iron(III) ions and form Prussian blue. This experiment should be done in a well-ventilated room, though... Same condition where you produced those elemental bromides should work. Also, the excessive cyanide can react with sulfur to gain a far less toxic ion of thiocyanate, which may work for getting rid of the leakage.
There might be some extra chemicals that co-condensed with hydrogen cyanide but according to Cody's experiment, that should not interfere much with the reaction... Also I think that after filtering the Prussian blue out, the unwanted waste should react with something like sodium thiosulfate to remove any cyanide residue just in case.
In all despite just being as a raw, unprocessed idea, I hope this can help with the unavailability of ferrocyanide ions in your experiment rather than buying it from the store... And once again, thank you for making the chemistry so elegantly magnificent and help others understand the real fun behind science!

Ideally oil paints come with very little oil content in them because of how one works in layers on the canvas. (Fat over Lean) So when mixing your pigment for use on the canvas, the first few layers should have very little oil content, which would require more fine mixing with a glass pestle (or just a palette knife and time) and a glass palette. (Or a thick piece of glass.) For your example of making a more fluid paint by thinning it with a solvent is one way of making it more "lean" but can cause archiving issues because it does break down the oil in the paint itself. (BTW student grade or lower paints have more oil in them to allow for straight out of the tube painting and most artist grade or higher often require a little thinning with oil/mediums to allow for more detail applications. IE, they are very thick.)

As for the substrate, cold press watercolor paper with a heavier weight or print making paper can be ideal of a surface to Gesso (Which is a sizer and ground.) and work on.

Making decent workable oil paint is much more complicated than the usually told mix with linseed oil, and is the most difficult paint to make. It contains waxes, extenders, solvents, more oils than just linseed and siccative agents. Watercolor is easier if your pigment is superbly well milled, just mix it with arabic gum and a bit of honey or glicerin, and let dry or not. It's the best to show a pigment for itself, but it must be well blended to the extreme. Pastels are easy too, pigment with a bit of (car) carnauba wax and various proportions of kaolin clay to set the darness of the bar.

I'm a painting student, and recently took a materials class where we learned to make all types of paint. It was very interesting to see how the pigments are made, since we used prepared powdered pigments. Some advice for your next painting endeavors: Acrylic would've been sooooo much easier to make than oil, which I found to be the most difficult to make. But if you do make oil paint again, as you said, don't add so much oil! Add very little at a time. High quality oil paint has very little oil in it, and is more like a thick paste than what you might imagine "paint" as, it is not liquidy at all. Instead, more oil and turpentine is added later when you use it, this is called "medium", and adding it later as you use the paint gives you much more control over the color and consistency. For your painting, consider starting with a more transparent "underpainting", and paint darker in subsequent layers to fill in detail. This technique will give you much more control!
We're all good at different things though, so I hope my tips can be helpful and interesting to you in the same was your video was interesting to me!

You'd have been better off working it into an acrylic medium or some sort. Oil paints don't just "work" on their own. You have the gesso as a substrate but you also need an built up background layer of paint to work on top of so it moves and spreads properly.  Wet on wet, or moreso "oily on sort of oily slightly dry."  Acrylic you can just go at it out of the tube and it'll spread and let you see the true pigment really easily. So if you see this before making future colors go for acrylic medium.

Fun fact: Ferric Chloride is a marvelous corrosive which you can use to etch copper plates for printing, as opposed to nitric acid, since it doesn't give off as much fumes. So there's a lot of arty applications beyond the pigment made in this video :)

One potentially interesting pathway for the potassium ferrocyanide, though I don't know if you can get much of a yield, might be to synthesize it from the cyanogenic glycosides in the toxic parts of plants. Many plants produce compounds which are enzymatically catalyzed into hydrogen cyanide as a defense mechanism. Bitter almonds and apricot pits are probably one of the more available sources for this and seem to be available for bulk purchase online. By grinding those seeds and soaking their powder/pulp in water you should be able to make a cyanic acid solution.

From there you could synthesize it from an alkaline aqueous solution of ferrous salts in a single step. Given your goals and what's readily available I'd suggest potassium carbonate, which can be attained from brewing supply stores or directly from a chemical supplier, and ferrous sulfide which you'll probably just have to order. Hydrogen cyanide should react to form potassium ferrocyanide, hydrogen sulfide, and CO2.

Alternatively there's a more well tested and easier to purify method based on how they do it in commercial production. By reacting the cyanic acid with calcium hydroxide (slaked lime) you'll form pretty straight forward calcium cyanide solution. From there heat it with ferrous sulfate(Iron supplement) to produce calcium ferrocyanide. This is obviously a step that necessitates a good fume hood. By adding potassium chloride (low sodium salt) you'll produce a nearly insoluble double salt of potassium calcium ferrocyanide which will fall out of solution. Filter and clean it with water. From there you just need to react it with a potassium carbonate solution. Insoluble calcium carbonate will fall out of solution and you'll be left with a crude potassium ferrocyanide solution. The product can be crystallized out as the trihydrate and purified further from there.

The reason for low toxicity of ferrocyanides is pretty simple. Most cyanides are poisonous because CN groups bond to ferrum in haemoglobin in blood disabling it's main function: oxygen transport, in a similar way as carbon monoxide does. In ferrocyanides CN is already bonded to ferrum and there is nothing it can actually do.
In Austria this is called the: Berliner Blau (Blue) for Fe3+ or Turnbulls Blau (Blue) for Fe2+

When it comes to the removal of cesium-137, there's also a product specialized into it, known as cesium eliminator.
It contains hydroxyaluminosilocates (from zeolite), seawater extract, dehydrated seaweed, Himalayan soirulina and chlorella cesium-137.
It has been tested in two labs with the usage of an ICP MS.
The chemical reason it's less likely to contaminate you with aluminium is over the fact that the silica groups bind with aluminium.
http://www.cesiumeliminator.com

You should try the wet-on-wet (oil-on-oil) method of painting, aka the Bob Ross method. You basically paint a canvas with white paint, and then apply colored paint directly on the white paint while it's still wet. It can look really good when done well, and it's fairly easy to do well. Watch Bob Ross videos for details. Also, you can do it with any type of paint except watercolor, although I think oil works the best due to the longer drying time.

I never made the K3[Fe(CN6)] myself, but have made the Cr version. This starts with Cr2(OAc)4(H2O)2 which gets reacted with KCN and then oxidized to form K3[Cr(CN)6]. It then needs to be recrystallized several times to get nice yellow crystals. I think the Fe route is easier since you don't have to work around the substitutionally inert Cr(III).
